data.text:
★★★★★

This is a “high-concept” masterpiece that arrived decades before the term was dreamt up by Hollywood. It’s a peerless European thriller (a French-Italian co-production), directed by Henri-Georges Clouzot and built on the most simple and propulsive premise: take two trucks, four men and more than 100 cans of highly volatile nitroglycerine and send them on a perilous 300-mile drive across a wild and rugged South American landscape (actual location: south of France). Then sit back and enjoy.

It’s essentially the black and white arthouse version of Speed, but so much better than that sounds. The character work is rich, especially Yves Montand as a self-hating ladies’ man. Clouzot’s directorial touches are ingenious, including a close-up of tobacco being blown off an open cigarette
